citations.narrative:
Feed and bedding intended for use for four black titi monkeys, two Venezuelan red howler monkeys, four bearded saki
and two red ruffed lemurs is stored improperly. At this facility, nonhuman primate bedding is stored together with feed and
bedding for other animals inside a storage outbuilding; some of the wooden shaving bedding is stored outside the storage
building, directly on the ground, and one of the bags is torn open to expose the shavings inside. Additionally, bags of
primate diet are stored directly up against the wall inside the storage building, and there are boxes of rodenticide stored
on the floor of the storage building, not far from the feed and bedding.
Food that is not properly stored is subject to deterioration and contamination due to chemical toxins, microbial growth or
pests and vermin, which can lead to animal illness. The licensee must ensure that all food and bedding is stored in a
manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, deterioration of nutrients, contamination and vermin infestation. These
supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. Only
the food and bedding currently being used may be kept in animal areas and when not in actual use, open food and
bedding supplies must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly fitting lids to prevent spoilage and contamination.
Substances that are toxic to nonhuman primates but that are required for normal husbandry practices must not be stored
in food storage or preparation areas, but may be stored in cabinets in animal areas.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 01/23/2026
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and attending veterinarian.
n

narrative:
3.75(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Feed and bedding intended for use for four black titi monkeys, two Venezuelan red howler monkeys, four bearded saki 
and two red ruffed lemurs is stored improperly. At this facility, nonhuman primate bedding is stored together with feed and 
bedding for other animals inside a storage outbuilding; some of the wooden shaving bedding is stored outside the storage 
building, directly on the ground, and one of the bags is torn open to expose the shavings inside. Additionally, bags of 
primate diet are stored directly up against the wall inside the storage building, and there are boxes of rodenticide stored 
on the floor of the storage building, not far from the feed and bedding. 
Food that is not properly stored is subject to deterioration and contamination due to chemical toxins, microbial growth or 
pests and vermin, which can lead to animal illness. The licensee must ensure that all food and bedding is stored in a 
manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, deterioration of nutrients, contamination and vermin infestation. These 
supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. Only 
the food and bedding currently being used may be kept in animal areas and when not in actual use, open food and 
bedding supplies must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly fitting lids to prevent spoilage and contamination. 
Substances that are toxic to nonhuman primates but that are required for normal husbandry practices must not be stored 
in food storage or preparation areas, but may be stored in cabinets in animal areas. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY 01/23/2026 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and attending veterinarian. 
 
 n

species.common: COLLARED TITI MONKEY, BLACK TITI, WIDOW MONKEY
